s.html: s is a unit of time represented in "seconds". Examples: 0s, 1.5s, -60s.
s.text: s is a unit of time represented in "seconds". Examples: 0s, 1.5s, -60s.

ms.html: ms is a unit of time represented in "milliseconds". 1000ms is 1s (second).
ms.text: ms is a unit of time represented in "milliseconds". 1000ms is 1s (second).

%.html: The <percentage> CSS data type represents a percentage value. It is often used to define a size as relative to an element's parent element. Numerous properties can use percentages, such as width, height, margin, padding, and font-size.
%.text: The % (percentage) CSS data type represents a percentage value. It is often used to define a size as relative to an element's parent element. Numerous properties can use percentages, such as width, height, margin, padding, and font-size.

cap.html: Represents the "cap height" (nominal height of capital letters) of the element’s font.
cap.text: Represents the "cap height" (nominal height of capital letters) of the element’s font.

ch.html: ch is a unit of length which equates to the width of the character 0, so width: 2ch; would be the width of 2 zeroes. This can change depending on the font-family you're using. Read more about ch and similar units.
ch.text: ch is a unit of length equal to the width of the character 0, so width: 2ch; would be the width of 2 zeroes. This can vary depending on the font-family you're using.

em.html: em is a unit of length which relates directly to font size. For example, if font-size: 10px; than width: 2em; would be a width of 20px. When applied to font-size: 1em; then it's relative to the inherited font-size, usually it's parent element's. Read more about em and similar units.
em.text: Rem is a unit of length related to font size. For example, if font-size: 10px; then width: 2em; would equal a width of 20px. When applied to font-size: 1em;, it's relative to the inherited font size, usually that of the parent element.

ex.html: Represents the x-height of the element's font. On fonts with the "x" letter, this is generally the height of lowercase letters in the font; 1ex ≈ 0.5em in many fonts.
ex.text: Represents the x-height of the element's font. On fonts with the "x" letter, this is generally the height of lowercase letters in the font; 1ex ≈ 0.5em in many fonts.

ic.html: Equal to the used advance measure of the "水" (CJK water ideograph, U+6C34) glyph found in the font used to render it.
ic.text: Equal to the used advance measure of the "水" (CJK water ideograph, U+6C34) glyph found in the font used to render it.

lh.html: Equal to the computed value of the line-height property of the element on which it is used, converted to an absolute length.
lh.text: Equal to the computed value of the line-height property of the element on which it is used, converted to an absolute length.

rem.html: rem is a unit of length which relates directly to font size of the "root" element (the <html>) which essentially means the browser's default font-size. For example, assuming the user has their browser's font-size set to 16px, a width: 2em; would equate to 32px. Read more about rem and similar units.
rem.text: rem is a unit of length related to the font size of the "root" element (the <html> tag), which generally means the browser's default font size. For example, if the user's browser font size is set to 16px, a width: 2rem; would equal 32px.

rlh.html: Equal to the computed value of the line-height property on the root element (typically <html>), converted to an absolute length. When used on the font-size or line-height properties of the root element, it refers to the properties' initial value.
rlh.text: Equal to the computed value of the line-height property on the root element (typically <html>), converted to an absolute length. When used on the font-size or line-height properties of the root element, it refers to the properties' initial value.

vh.html: vh stands for "viewport height", the viewport is the "viewable portion" of your document, meaning everything you currently see in your window. You can think of vh as a percentage of the window's height (as opposed to the % which is always relative to the parent element).
vh.text: vh stands for "viewport height," which refers to the visible portion of your document—everything you currently see in your window. You can think of vh as a percentage of the window's height, unlike %, which is always relative to the parent element.

vw.html: vw stands for "viewport width", the viewport is the "viewable portion" of your document, meaning everything you currently see in your window. You can think of vw as a percentage of the window's width (as opposed to the % which is always relative to the parent element).
vw.text: vw stands for "viewport width," which refers to the visible portion of your document—everything you currently see in your window. You can think of vw as a percentage of the window's width, unlike %, which is always relative to the parent element.

vi.html: Equal to 1% of the size of the initial containing block, in the direction of the root element’s inline axis.
vi.text: Equal to 1% of the size of the initial containing block, in the direction of the root element’s inline axis.

vb.html: Equal to 1% of the size of the initial containing block, in the direction of the root element’s block axis.
vb.text: Equal to 1% of the size of the initial containing block, in the direction of the root element’s block axis.

vmin.html: Equal to the smaller of vw and vh.
vmin.text: Equal to the smaller of vw and vh.

vmax.html: Equal to the larger of vw and vh.
vmax.text: Equal to the larger of vw and vh.

px.html: px or "pixel" is a unit of length representing one device pixel (dot), the smallest discrete element of an image on your screen.
px.text: px or "pixel" is a unit of length representing one device pixel (dot), the smallest discrete element of an image on your screen.

Q.html: One quarter of a millimeter. 1Q = 1/40th of 1cm.
Q.text: One quarter of a millimeter. 1Q = 1/40th of 1cm.

deg.html: deg is an angle, a unit of rotation measured in "degrees". One full circle is 360deg.
deg.text: deg is an angle unit used to measure rotation in "degrees." One full circle is 360deg. Read more about angles.

grad.html: grad is an angle, a unit of rotation measured in "gradians". One full circle is 400grad.
grad.text: grad is an angle unit used to measure rotation in "gradians." One full circle is 400grad. Read more about angles.

rad.html: rad is an angle, a unit of rotation measured in "radians". One full circle is 2π radians or roughly 6.2832rad.
rad.text: rad is an angle unit used to measure rotation in "radians." One full circle is 2π radians, or roughly 6.2832rad. Read more about angles.

turn.html: turn is an angle, a unit of rotation measured in "turns". One full circle is 1turn.
turn.text: turn is an angle unit used to measure rotation in "turns." One full circle is 1turn. Read more about angles.

fr.html: The <flex> CSS data type denotes a flexible length within a grid container. It is used in grid-template-columns, grid-template-rows and other related properties.
fr.text: The <flex> CSS data type denotes a flexible length within a grid container. It is used in grid-template-columns, grid-template-rows and other related properties

dpi.html: Represents the number of dots per inch. Screens typically contains 72 or 96 dots per inch, but the dpi for printed documents is usually much greater. As 1 inch is 2.54 cm, 1dpi ≈ 0.39dpcm.
dpi.text: Represents the number of dots per inch. Screens typically contains 72 or 96 dots per inch, but the dpi for printed documents is usually much greater. As 1 inch is 2.54 cm, 1dpi ≈ 0.39dpcm.

dpcm.html: Represents the number of dots per centimeter. As 1 inch is 2.54 cm, 1dpcm ≈ 2.54dpi.
dpcm.text: Represents the number of dots per centimeter. As 1 inch is 2.54 cm, 1dpcm ≈ 2.54dpi.

dppx.html: Represents the number of dots per px unit. Due to the 1:96 fixed ratio of CSS in to CSS px, 1dppx is equivalent to 96dpi, which corresponds to the default resolution of images displayed in CSS as defined by image-resolution.
dppx.text: Represents the number of dots per px unit. Due to the 1:96 fixed ratio of CSS in to CSS px, 1dppx is equivalent to 96dpi, which corresponds to the default resolution of images displayed in CSS as defined by image-resolution.

x.html: Alias for dppx, which represents the number of dots per px unit. Due to the 1:96 fixed ratio of CSS in to CSS px, 1dppx is equivalent to 96dpi, which corresponds to the default resolution of images displayed in CSS as defined by image-resolution.
x.text: Alias for dppx, which represents the number of dots per px unit. Due to the 1:96 fixed ratio of CSS in to CSS px, 1dppx is equivalent to 96dpi, which corresponds to the default resolution of images displayed in CSS as defined by image-resolution.

number.html: The <number> CSS data type represents a number, being either an integer or a number with a fractional component.
number.text: The number CSS data type represents a number, being either an integer or a number with a fractional component.
